doc.field: Local elections are taking place in Schleswig-Holstein today. The provincial electoral office in Kiel said that voting had started quietly. 2.2 million voter will vote for city, district communal and communal parliaments. Very few young people had voted by Sunday afternoon. Sixteen-year-olds in Schleswig-Holstein were able to vote in local elections for the first time. In addition, around 30000 voters from other EU states were also entitled to vote in these elections. These elections are considered to be a test run for the national German elections in September. It is therefore of interest to see whether the SPD will be able to assert themselves as the strongest party three weeks after winning the state election in Lower Saxony. Four years ago the SPD achieved 39.5 percent of the vote, while the CDU attained only 37.5 percent.

Mr. Freitag, the chairman of the board for the Federal Social Insurance Office for Salaried Employees (BfA) has made some new suggestions regarding compulsory social insurance deductions for people employed under the 620 Mark basis. He used Austria as an example where small firms or private households do not have to deduct social insurance contributions for employees earning less than a certain income. However, large firms are prevented from splitting a full-time job over several part-time employees in order to avoid paying social insurance contributions. Mr. Freitag represents the Unions on the Board of the BfA.
Still no hot lead in Christina murder case

The Police in Lower Saxony report that they still do not have any hot leads in the Christina murder case. The autopsy yesterday evening [Saturday] of the eleven-year-old girl indicate that she had been sexually assaulted and strangled. According to the Police, Christina had stab wounds as well. No information was given as to the time of death; Christina was abducted last Monday. The police are still searching for clues at the site at which the body was found in Emsland. 60 police officers have been allocated to a special commission for the case.where they are also investigating possible links to another case of a missing person in the region. A thirteen-year-old girl has disappeared without trace about two years ago. The reward for information leading to capture of the murderer has been increased to DM 70,000.
Disagreement amongst Greens regarding taxing diesel fuel

Husstett, the spokeswoman on political environmental matters for the parliamentary fraction for the Greens, has contradicted statements made by Ms. Seibold, a party colleague, regarding the taxation of aeronautic diesel fuel. Ms. Husstett said that the diesel fuel tax was supported by the government, but that Germany could not act on its own regarding this tax. It would only make sense if it were introduced to the whole of Europe, she said. Ms. Seibold had said to the newspaper "Bild am Sonntag" that the Green party would like to drastically increase the price of aeronautic diesel fuel to encourage holiday makers to use more environmentally friendly means of transport. She said that it was sufficient for Germans to fly overseas once every five years. Ms. Husstett contradicted this statement as well. She said that it has nothing to do with politicians where and when someone spends their holiday.
Britain wants to reduce troops on the Rhine

The British government wants to decrease the size of its troops on the Rhine. According to a report in the "Sunday Times", more than 3000 soldiers will be withdrawn from Germany. Till now there have been more than 17000 soldiers stationed in Germany. According to the newspaper, the government in London hopes to be able to save money with these measures. Furthermore, they intend to reorganize the armed forces on the Rhine into a special force on alert for emergencies to assist NATO and the UN in peace missions worldwide.

Industry invested almost 33 billion marks into so-called direct marketing. Consumers thus receive ever increasing advertising material by post, fax or email. Addresses are bought mostly from special agents. These figures were quoted by the Institute for Direct marketing in Stuttgart. The Institute forecasts that this type of advertising will increase even more and will even play a role in the coming German national elections.
Record high number of houses built in 1997

Over 570000 freestanding houses were built last year in Germany said Mr. Oswald, the Federal Minister of Building and Construction. This was an increase of around two percent in comparison to last year. Mr. Oswald said that this record was due to the current favorable interest rates, decreased building costs and, in part, lower prices for land for building. He appealed to local communities, particularly those in conurbations, to make available more land for building.
